Graphical abstract The construction of functional catalysts that efficiently catalyze in a reducing atmosphere is considered rather challenging. In this study, the catalysts bridged by Bi-N4 between copper and bismuth species were prepared. Herein, Bi-N4 and bismuth cluster sites were incorporated into porous carbon–nitrogen networks along with copper nanoparticles (BiSAC&Clu-Cu-NC). For the synthesis, metalloporphyrin-modified HKUST-1 (TCPP(Bi)@HKUST-1) was employed as a precursor. Additionally, metalloporphyrin functioned as a capping agent during catalyst preparation, thereby enhancing the dispersion of Bi species after calcination. Notably, the BiSAC&Clu-Cu-NC catalyst demonstrated 93.8 % selectivity towards 1,4-butynediol over 20 h at a Bi loading of 0.6 wt% in a reducing atmosphere of acetylene and formaldehyde. Furthermore, a mechanistic model is proposed that elucidates the observed synergistic catalytic behavior based on experimental characterization and DFT calculations. This proposed model is termed “Nanoparticles with Cluster and Single Metal Sites”(NCS mechanism). The retention of the Bi cluster structure within the material matrix plays a pivotal role in enhancing the adsorption and activation of formaldehyde. Interfacial effects between different copper species favour the activation of the reaction substrate acetylene. Additionally, the Bi-N4 structure can function as a crucial conduit, facilitating electron transfer between Cu and Bi elements and consequently lowering the activation energy barrier for key reaction intermediates. The formaldehyde-acetylene reaction is vital for the production of 1,4-butynediol, which serves as a feedstock to production 1,4-butanediol. Given the importance of this reaction in applications, improving the efficiency and stability of catalysts used in this process is essential. Previous research on catalysts used in the formaldehyde ethynylation. process has primarily focused on establishing robust interactions between Cu and inert support, incorporating oxidizing additives, and harnessing the long-range electromagnetic influence of noble metals [2–4]. These endeavors aim to regulate the chemical environment surrounding Cu+ ions and ensure their stability in reducing atmosphere. Nevertheless, preserving the stability of Cu+ species under reducing conditions poses a significant challenge, frequently resulting in diminished catalytic performance and reduced selectivity. In reactions such as the conversion of formaldehyde and acetylene to 1,4-butynediol, the stability of Cu+ active sites are crucial, as high selectivity is directly dependent on the stability of these sites. To overcome this issue, the present study focuses on designing a novel copper-bismuth catalyst with Bi-N4 sites and Bi clusters. These components are anticipated to enhance the stability of Cu+ species in reducing environments, consequently improving both selectivity and catalytic efficiency. In response to these challenges, researchers have explored advanced catalyst designs incorporating metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). MOFs have been extensively employed in the construction of sacrificial templates for single atoms, clusters, and nanomaterials due to their adjustable structural functions, regular channels, and ultra-high surface area [5–7]. Furthermore, metalloporphyrin is frequently employed as ligands in MOF modification, promoting the formation of M−N4 sites [8–10]. Besides, the characteristic out-of-plane (OOP) structure of metalloporphyrin serves as a capping agent for MOFs [11]. The carbon-loaded copper bismuth materials derived from MOFs enhance acetylene adsorption and mitigate the issue of carbon accumulation, thereby preventing alterations in the Cu+ microenvironment [12–14]. Beyond MOF-derived materials, transition metal species of different scales, including single atoms, nanoclusters, and nanoparticles, have demonstrated significant potential for enhancing catalytic performance in a wide range of reactions. Transition metal species of varying sizes, including single atoms, nanoclusters, and nanoparticles, exhibit distinct catalytic behaviors in various heterogeneous catalytic reactions [15,16]. Notably, there is a widespread aspiration to elucidate these relationships at the molecular level. Recently, Li et al. used the wetness impregnation method to construct dual-site Pd1-Ru1 supported on porous ionic polymers [17]. In addition to enhancing the overall activity, the synergistic effect between neighboring single-site Pd1 and Ru1 also stabilizes Pd (II) active sites. This exploration of synergistic effects between dual monometallic sites provides a comprehensive understanding of materials at the molecular level. Zhang et al. employed the atomic layer deposition method to present a facile method for decorating atomically dispersed Pt co-catalysts with single-atom and atomic cluster dual active sites on CdS nanorods [18]. According to experimental characterizations and theoretical calculations, single atoms (SAs) are responsible for water adsorption-dissociation and atomic cluster sites are responsible for hydrogen desorption. This study underscores the significance of synergistic interactions between monometallic and cluster-active sites to improve reaction efficiency. Chandrasekaran et al. used γ-cyclodextrin-based MOF as a precursor to synthesize bifunctional nitrogen-carbon metal catalysts containing M−Nx coordination sites and M/MxC nanoparticles (M = Co, Fe, and Cu) [19]. According to the density functional theory (DFT) calculations, Co nanoparticles (NPs) and Co single-atom catalysts (SACs) improved reaction kinetics via the fast adsorption/desorption of reaction intermediates. This improvement is attributed to the mutual self-regulation of the d electron densities of NPs and SACs, which jointly lowers the energy barrier, and the synergistic effects between single atoms and nanoparticles are revealed. Ding et al. utilized a direct CNT bridging strategy to prepare an efficient and robust catalyst for a bifunctional oxygen electrode [20]. The obtained catalyst simultaneously features a high concentration of single-atom Fe-N5 active sites and nanosized NiCo hydroxides. Moreover, the synergistic catalytic effect of single-atom and alloy nanoparticles is well demonstrated. Recently, Meng et al. reported a NiFe-N-C catalyst with bimetallic synergistic Fe nanoclusters [21]. The DFT calculations and characterization provide compelling evidence for the coexistence and electronic synergies of the Ni-N4 and Fe-N4 coordination structures, as well as the neighboring coupled Fe nanoclusters. It must be noted that these structures modulate the electronic structure of the catalytically active sites and optimize their adsorption and desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates, consequently enhancing the reaction kinetics and lowering the energy barrier to oxygen electrocatalysis. The further exploration of the synergistic interactions between double single atoms and nanoclusters in this study led to the synthesis of a highly active catalyst derived from MOFs that is suitable for use in reducing atmospheres. Additionally, we conducted a corresponding catalytic mechanistic analysis. Building on these findings, this study presents a novel strategy that employs, for the first time, Bi-N4 and Bi clusters to synergistically stabilize Cu+/Cu0 active interface. This strategy demonstrates high selectivity towards the target product under reducing conditions, emphasizing the potential for practical applications. Notably, experiments have demonstrated the beneficial role of cluster structures in the adsorption of the reaction substrate. Moreover, formaldehyde undergoes overoxidation in the absence of Bi-N4 structures, resulting in decreased product selectivity. Both calculations and experiments demonstrate that the Bi-N4 structure acts as a bridge for electron transfer between Bi and Cu species, stabilizing the valence states of active metals. Furthermore, this mechanism effectively inhibits substrate peroxidation, which reduces the activation energy required for transition state formation and transformation during the reaction. Thus, this study presents a novel strategy for enhancing the stability of active metals and achieving highly active catalytic performance under reducing conditions. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The materials used were bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, Adamas, 99 %), 1, 3, 5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC, 98 %, Adamas Co. Ltd.), copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Macklin, 99 %), and 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP, 99 %, Adamas Co. Ltd.). N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF, AR), ethanol, and formaldehyde were purchased from Macklin Co., Ltd. Ultrapure (UP) water was used for all experiments. 2.2 Synthesis of Bi metalloporphyrin (TCPP(Bi)) Herein, for the synthesis, 50 mg of TCPP and 50 mg of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF through stirring and ultrasonically treated for 30 min. This mixture was subsequently transferred to a polytetrafluoroethylene lining. It was then heated in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h. The resultant purple powder was rinsed with UP water and ethanol to produce TCPP(Bi), which was subsequently centrifuged at 10,000 rpm and dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. 2.3 Synthesis of TCPP(Bi)@HKUST-1 A certain amount of TCPP(Bi) (0–8 mg) was dissolved in 8 mL of DMF. Then, 483.1 mg (2 mmol) of Cu (NO3)2·3H2O and 210 mg (1.0 mmol) of H3BTC were dissolved in 12 mL of ethanol. These two solutions were thoroughly mixed by stirring and were then transferred to a 25-mL PTFE liner and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The resulting blue-green precipitate was centrifuged, washed several times with ethanol, and dried overnight at 80 °C. 2.4 Synthesis of MOF-derived carbon carrier materials The carbon carrier materials were obtained by annealing the as-prepared TCPP(Bi)@HKUST-1 composites with varied TCPP(Bi) loading contents in argon at 400 °C (2 °C/min) for 4 h. Based on the differences in dispersion, the samples were referred to as BiNPS-Cu-NC, BiClu-Cu-NC, BiSAC&Clu-Cu-NC, and BiSAC-Cu-NC. For comparison, the MOF-derived carbon carrier materials prepared by the impregnation and bimetallic methods were named Bi-Cu-C and Bi&Cu-C, respectively. Bimetallic method: replace TCPP(Bi) in the above preparation method with 10 mg of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, followed by the same synthesis. Impregnation method: 10 mg of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of 4 % dilute nitric acid solution, 1 g of Cu-BTC precursor was taken in the above solution and stirred at 600 rpm for 12 h. The obtained product was filtered, washed, and dried at 80 ℃ for 12 h, and then the dried solid phase was put into a tube furnace, and burned in an Ar atmosphere at 400 ℃ for 4 h, and the heating rate of the tube furnace was 2 ℃/min. 2.5 Catalyst evaluation All catalytic tests of the ethynylation of formaldehyde with acetylene were performed in a kettle reactor. A specified amount of catalysts (300 mg) and approximately 20 mL of formaldehyde (3 wt%) water solution were added together in an autoclave. Before the reaction, O2 was purged through a pure N2 flow for safety reasons, and then C2H2 was introduced into the kettle once the N2 flow stopped. After reaching 11.5 mmol (0.3 g), C2H2 was stopped, and the solution was continuously agitated and heated to 90 °C. The catalytic reaction was terminated after 20 h by introducing an N2 stream and turning off the C2H2 stream, and the mixture was cooled to room temperature. All the calculations are carried out in the framework of the density functional theory using the projector augmented plane-wave method, which is implemented in the Vienna Atomic Bomb Simulation Package [22]. The generalized gradient approximation proposed by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerh of is selected for the exchange–correlation potential [23]. The long-range van der Waals interaction is described by the DFT-D3 method [24]. The cut-off energy of the plane wave was set to 500 eV. In the iterative solution of the Kohn-Sham equation, the energy criterion was set to 10–6 eV. To avoid artificial interactions between the periodic images, a vacuum layer of 15 Å was added perpendicular to the direction of the sheet. The K-mesh resolved in real space is 0.04 2π/Å. All the structures are relaxed until the residual forces on the atoms have dropped to less than 0.05 eV/Å. From the characterization and DFT analyses, a synergistic catalytic mechanism, termed the “NCS mechanism,” has been proposed for the acetylene-formaldehyde reaction on the BiSAC&Clu-Cu-NC catalyst (see Fig. 6c). Initially, the H in the terminal ≡C-H of acetylene is replaced by Cu+ in the presence of acetylene to form Cu2C2. The presence of a carbon carrier facilitates the adsorption of acetylene and helps in activating acetylene molecules. Cu+/Cu0 interface favours the enhancement of terminal carbon-negativity of acetylene. Subsequently, formaldehyde molecules adsorb onto the Bi cluster structure to form + CHOH. Notably, the Bi cluster structure enhances the electropositivity of formaldehyde carbon, facilitating the attack of negatively charged acetylene carbon to form a transition state HC≡CCH2O – (TS-1), which does not exist stably. Thus, HC≡CCH2O – undergoes structural reorganization under the influence of Cu+ species, transforming into another transition state, - C≡CCH2OH (TS-2). During the transition between the two states, the N element in the Bi-N4 structure acts as a bridge for electron transfer between Cu and Bi elements, effectively promoting the stability of the active center of Cu + and reducing the activation energy for the formation of reaction intermediates. Further nucleophilic addition between formaldehyde and - C≡CCH2OH leads to the generation of – OH2CC≡CCH2OH, eventually resulting in the formation and desorption of the product BD. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, this study presents a material comprising Bi-N4 sites, Bi clusters, and Cu nanoparticles supported on an N-doped C network. Herein, the TCPP(Bi)@HKUST-1 was meticulously synthesized in situ, utilizing Bi metalloporphyrin as a ligand. Furthermore, Bi clusters and Bi-N4 sites were generated via the calcination processes. To reveal the synergistic effect among the Bi cluster, Bi-N4 structure, and intrinsic copper nanoparticles in the catalyst BiSAC&Clu-Cu-NC, the NCS mechanism was proposed and characterized through experimental methods and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Cu+/Cu0 interface favours acetylene adsorption and enhances carbon negativity at the alkyne terminus. The unique function of the Bi-N4 structure has been identified as a conduit for efficient electron transfer between copper and bismuth, effectively promoting the stability of the Cu+/Cu0 active interface. This facilitates the lowering of the energy barriers of the transition state and stabilizes the copper valence state to form the active species, acetylenic cuprous. Furthermore, the specific configuration of the catalyst Bi clusters is vital in promoting the adsorption and activation of formaldehyde molecules. This synergy has resulted in an impressive selectivity of 93.8 % to produce 1,4-butynediol, highlighting the efficacy and potential of the catalyst for practical applications. coredata.dc:description: The construction of functional catalysts that efficiently catalyze in a reducing atmosphere is considered rather challenging. In this study, the catalysts bridged by Bi-N4 between copper and bismuth species were prepared. Herein, Bi-N4 and bismuth cluster sites were incorporated into porous carbon–nitrogen networks along with copper nanoparticles (BiSAC&Clu-Cu-NC). For the synthesis, metalloporphyrin-modified HKUST-1 (TCPP(Bi)@HKUST-1) was employed as a precursor. Additionally, metalloporphyrin functioned as a capping agent during catalyst preparation, thereby enhancing the dispersion of Bi species after calcination. Notably, the BiSAC&Clu-Cu-NC catalyst demonstrated 93.8 % selectivity towards 1,4-butynediol over 20 h at a Bi loading of 0.6 wt% in a reducing atmosphere of acetylene and formaldehyde. Furthermore, a mechanistic model is proposed that elucidates the observed synergistic catalytic behavior based on experimental characterization and DFT calculations. This proposed model is termed “Nanoparticles with Cluster and Single Metal Sites”(NCS mechanism). The retention of the Bi cluster structure within the material matrix plays a pivotal role in enhancing the adsorption and activation of formaldehyde. Interfacial effects between different copper species favour the activation of the reaction substrate acetylene. Additionally, the Bi-N4 structure can function as a crucial conduit, facilitating electron transfer between Cu and Bi elements and consequently lowering the activation energy barrier for key reaction intermediates.
